file_content.text: Yes, sir.
As you say.
Not really the time for a debriefing.
Talking won't accomplish our mission objectives.
I'm looking forward to working with you, Master Jedi.
Your defeat of the Sith Emperor is a remarkable accomplishment. The whole Republic is in your debt.
And I'm certain that your future missions will be even more dangerous.
Remain with us, Sergeant. I'm sure we'll have need of your skills.
You're welcome to stay.
If there is something out there worse than the Emperor, Sergeant, I don't want to meet it.
I certainly hope not.
I'll be returning you to the military as soon as possible.
Not likely.
Master Jedi, the defeat of the Sith Empire is easily the most ambitious mission I have ever been given.
In fact, the odds of surviving a battle against the Emperor himself are almost zero.
I'm looking forward to this more than any other assignment I have ever had.
We're going to need everything we've got to defeat the Emperor.
I'm sure you'll be useful.
Understood, Master Jedi. Victory or death!
That's... unexpected. Why, exactly?
You are?
I've been waiting my whole life for a chance to deliver a decisive victory to the Republic.
If I may say so, the Jedi Order's discipline, self-sacrifice and devotion to duty are a model for all citizens.
It will be an honor to serve with you.
I didn't ask for you, and I don't need you here.
Just stay out of the way.
Understood.
When I was first given this assignment, I believed it would be an excellent opportunity to serve the Republic.
I underestimated. It has been the greatest honor of my life.
You can serve with my squad any time, Sergeant.
You'll always be welcome here.
The honor has been all mine, Sergeant Rusk.
It's been mutual.
Thank you, Master Jedi.
Fair warning: If you try to hug me, you may lose an arm.
Don't get mushy on me.
I wouldn't dream of it, Master Jedi.
I promise you, I'll train this squad to be the most efficient fighting machine in the Republic! Even the droid!
I'm with you until the bitter end! Victory or death!
Permission to speak freely, Master Jedi?
You've never needed permission to speak your mind before, Rusk.
You don't have to ask, Rusk.
What I'm about to say, Master Jedi, you might construe as critical.
Proceed, Sergeant.
Granted.
Thank you.
I'm busy, Rusk. This isn't going to take long, is it?
Is this important?
I'll be brief.
I had some concerns when I was first assigned to your squad.
The Jedi are known for their discipline and selflessness... and for their pacifist philosophies. I'm pleased to say my concerns were unfounded.
After Hoth, I'm not sure why you would have thought I was a pacifist.
You met me on a battlefield.
As I said, my concerns were unfounded.
I do what I must to fulfill my duties as a Jedi.
I serve the light side.
There are very few problems I don't solve with my lightsaber, Rusk.
You had nothing to worry about.
I only wish everyone shared your outlook on things.
I came from a pacifist colony, Master Jedi. We were bullied remorselessly: by pirates, corporations, Hutts, even governments.
I joined the military as soon as I could. Peace only comes to those willing to fight for it.
That must make things a little strained.
Does your family approve?
I'm sure your family is glad you're defending them, even if you disagree with their ideals.
So now you protect them.
Ten years ago, the colony was attacked by the Sith. My family was killed.
They never fought back. The Sith crushed them, the way you might step on a bug.
By the time we're through, Rusk, the Empire will regret leaving the Unknown Regions.
The Empire will pay for that.
We'll hold the Emperor accountable for this, Rusk. I promise.
We'll avenge them.
Thank you, Master Jedi.
They died for their principles. That's as honorable a death as one can achieve. Not everyone has such courage.
A noble sacrifice.
Courage? Honor? Hmm... perhaps.
They should have stood up for themselves. That's not principle, it's just stupidity.
They were weak.
Indeed.
At least as a soldier you can make yourself useful.
That's about all you could do.
At any rate, we should move on. Thank you for hearing me out.
I've been analyzing your battle tactics, Master Jedi. I hope you don't mind.
I believe I've found a way to increase my own combat efficiency by another twenty-five point four percent.
Why don't we try out your new tactics in the field?
Sounds like something to test.
I was hoping you'd say that, Master Jedi.
I'm happy to provide a good example for you, Sergeant.
Glad to be of service.
It's an honor to serve with you, Master Jedi. May I suggest we return to the field? I'd like to test these new tactics.
You can use all the help you can get, Sergeant.
Keep studying.
Yes, Master Jedi.
My old squad-mates were good soldiers when I knew them. Still can't believe how they ended up.
If I hadn't been reassigned after that first mission... I might have been one of them.
You wouldn't have endured innocent blood on your hands. You're not like them, Sergeant.
You're better than they are.
No. I'm not.
Don't waste your time on what might have been.
Yes, well, you're not.
You're right, of course.
Are you wishing you'd stayed with them?
Regrets, Rusk?
I either would've had to kill them, or join them. Either way, it would've ended my career as a soldier.
It's a far greater honor to be assigned to your squad, Master Jedi.
We've already taken down the Emperor. I look forward to facing whatever challenges lie ahead.
I look forward to the day we face the Emperor together.
Finally tracked down my old squad-mates, master Jedi. Wishing I hadn't.
General Garza recruited them into the Special Forces black ops program, but now they're in a detention facility on Berrun--convicted of war crimes.
War crimes are a serious charge. How did your old squad go from being heroes to convicted criminals?
That's awful news.
Black ops doesn't make heroes. It trains killers. If the right targets die, no one complains.
Black ops are supposed to be secret. Who gave you this information?
How did you learn this?
It started as a nasty rumor from Imperial propaganda, but the detention center's warden confirmed everything.
Sounds like your old friends enjoyed their work more than they were supposed to.
I guess they had too much fun.
Good soldiers are like Jedi. They don't act on emotion.
They renamed my old squad "the Surgeons." Tasked them with destabilizing the Empire's command structure by removing its best leaders.
But the Surgeons didn't just target Imperial commanders--they went after the officers' families. They wanted to send the enemy a message.
Killing women and children is never acceptable.
They crossed the line.
Good soldiers know what acceptable targets are. This wouldn't have happened on my watch.
I wouldn't put it past the Empire to frame your old squad.
You're sure they did it?
I wondered the same thing, but the fact is they all confessed. They're proud of what they did.
That's the sort of communication the Empire needs more of.
I approve that message.
Killing civilians only gives the enemy more resolve. Puts their backs against the wall.
The detention center's warden says my old squad-mates are serving life sentences. They're young. That's a lot of years to spend in cages.
The next time I get nostalgic and curious, master Jedi... give me a planet to invade.
Master Jedi, our downtime has had a positive impact on my battle-readiness.
I believe I'm fourteen point two percent more prepared for combat now.
What? What does that even mean?
How do you get these numbers?
It's a statistical analysis of--well... I won't bore you with the details.
It's good to know you've been using your time wisely, Sergeant.
I'm glad to hear it.
Fourteen percent more of nothing is still nothing.
That's not saying much.
Thank you for the observation.
I've had a lot of time to think. I'd forgotten what that was like.
Relax while you can, Sergeant. There's more fighting ahead.
Enjoy it while it lasts.
I'm looking forward to it.
You'd forgotten what downtime was like, or you'd forgotten what thinking was like?
Which part, dummy?
I won't tolerate laziness, Sergeant.
Don't get too comfortable.
Of course, Master Jedi.
I've been thinking about my original squad. I haven't seen any of them since we liberated that POW camp.
They seem to be on active duty, but I can't find any mention of commendations or recognition. They should be decorated soldiers.
I'm sure you'll find something.
Keep looking.
Perhaps they're not as good as you thought.
Maybe they're not decorated.
I can't imagine their careers have been less impressive than my own.
They were soldiers under your command. Statistically, they should be corpses.
Or dead.
Yes, but they were better than the statistical average. They beat the odds.
Karsim, Naja, Eckerd... that whole squad has simply vanished.
They're probably just posted somewhere far from the fighting.
I'm sure they're fine.
That seems like a terrible waste of skilled personnel.
One might almost believe that you considered those soldiers people.
You sound worried.
They'd be most valuable to the Republic deployed on the front. This just doesn't make sense to me.
Forget them. They're not relevant now.
They're not important.
Understood, Master Jedi.
Master Jedi, I'm aware that my recent military record might raise some concerns.
I want to reassure you that my squad fatality rates have not consistently been this high.
I suppose that's... good to hear.
That's... reassuring.
So you only lose all of your men some of the time?
"Not consistently"?
Nothing matters but the success of the mission, Sergeant.
Just get results.
Exactly, Master Jedi.
The first squad I commanded after making sergeant was sent to free POWs being held at a small Imperial outpost.
Intel said the place would be lightly manned. Most of the Imperials wouldn't arrive for another twenty-four hours. Intel was wrong.
The outpost wasn't lightly manned, or the POWs weren't being held there?
On what count?
I assume you got more than you bargained for.
You ran into trouble.
The Imperials sent their reinforcements a day early. When my squad broke into the outpost, we were outnumbered ten-to-one.
We were outmanned and outgunned, but we achieved our objective, freed all the POWs, and came out alive.
My squad's casualty rate was ninety-seven point four percent, but we had no fatalities.
It's impressive that anyone made it out of there with those odds.
Congratulations.
They were good soldiers. Far better than any of the others I've had under my command.
If ninety-seven percent casualties is your best, Sergeant, I'd hate to hear your worst.
And that's your success story?
Another time, Master Jedi.
Barely scraping by is hardly a victory, Sergeant.
That's pathetic.
Just tell me what you're getting at, Sergeant.
Is there a point to this?
Our mission was accomplished without permanent loss of Republic resources.
That squad was effectively trained, and as a result, we achieved victory much more efficiently.
They must have been remarkable soldiers.
They were certainly skilled.
They are.
Then the death tolls are simply a matter of poor resource use?
So it's just about efficiency?
Good soldiers are a resource. Yes, their loss damages the war effort, but they are meant to be used.
Victory for the Republic is worth any cost.
I think I've heard enough for the moment.
Sergeant, just stop talking.
Yes, Master Jedi.
I have a report that's for your ears only, Master Jedi. I'll deliver it back on the ship.
I'll deliver my report as soon as we're in a secure location, Master Jedi.
Nothing to report at present, Master Jedi.
Never minded walking through enemy territory, long as the ammo holds out.
I'm with you until the bitter end! Victory or death!
Good soldiers are like Jedi. They don't act on emotion.
Victory for the Republic is worth any cost.
Live like a coward, die like one.
Any Sith who comes after you gets a face full of blaster.
Hesitation loses battles. So does insubordination.
I'm honored to serve on such an important mission. Victory or death.
Weapons armed. Just say the word.
As ordered, Master Jedi.
